simpledes: Post-tax private income corresponds to all sources of incomes, net of taxes, received by individuals and which can be individualized (this excludes social transfers in kind, collective consumption expenditure and government deficit).
technicaldes: Post-tax disposable income=Pre-tax income-Taxes on production (net)-Current taxes on income and wealth+Social assistance benefits in cash
longtype: Average income or wealth between two percentiles. When the associated percentile is of the form 'pX', intermediary average returns the average between percentile pX and the next consecutive percentile. When the associated percentile is of the form 'pXpY', the variable returns the average between percentiles pX and pY.
longpop: The base unit is the individual (rather than the household) but resources are split equally within couples.
longage: The population is comprised of individuals over age 20.
source: Blanchet, Chancel and Gethin (2020), “Why is Europe less Unequal than the United States?”
method: Summary of data construction by year (see source for details): 1980: extrapolated distribution, 1981-1985: interpolated survey + concept correction + tax data, 1986: survey + concept correction + tax data, 1987-1990: interpolated survey + concept correction + tax data, 1991: survey + concept correction + tax data, 1992-1993: interpolated survey + concept correction + tax data, 1994-1995: survey + concept correction + tax data, 1996-1998: interpolated survey + concept correction + tax data, 1999: survey + concept correction + tax data, 2000-2003: interpolated survey + concept correction + tax data, 2004: survey + tax data, 2005: interpolated survey + tax data, 2006-2014: survey + tax data, 2015: extrapolated distribution using survey data, 2016-2017: extrapolated distribution

simpledes: Consumption of fixed capital of national economy is the decline in total value of fixed assets (e.g. roads, machines) which are owned and used by a producer. In other words, the amounts required to maintain the quality of fixed assets from a year to another. The decline in  value is a result of physical deterioration, normal obsolescence or normal accidental damage.The national economy - in the national accounts sense - includes all domestic sectors, i.e. all entities that are resident of a given country (in the sense of their economic activity), whether they belong to the private sector, the corporate sector, the governement sector.
longtype: Average income or wealth between two percentiles. When the associated percentile is of the form 'pX', intermediary average returns the average between percentile pX and the next consecutive percentile. When the associated percentile is of the form 'pXpY', the variable returns the average between percentiles pX and pY.
longpop: The base unit is the individual (rather than the household). This is equivalent to assuming no sharing of resources within couples.
longage: The population is comprised of individuals over age 20.
source: See DINA guidelines for methodological explanations.
method: WID.world estimations as a proportion of GDP based on the following; 1855–2019: imputed value. These estimates are then anchored to GDP (see GDP variable for details).

When the associated percentile is of the form 'pX', intermediary average returns the average between percentile pX and the next consecutive percentile. When the associated percentile is of the form 'pXpY', the variable returns the average between percentiles pX and pY.
longpop: The base unit is the individual (rather than the household). This is equivalent to assuming no sharing of resources within couples.
longage: The population is comprised of individuals over age 20.

simpledes: Corporate non-financial assets are assets with a physical value (real estate, machinery, equipment, etc.) owned by the corporate sector (companies). The corporate sector - in the national accounts sense - includes all financial and non-financial corporations with an economic activity in a given country, whatever their legal status (with the exceptions of unincorporated enterprises included in the personal sector).

technicaldes: [Post-tax national income]=[Post-tax disposable income]+[Public spending]
longtype: Average income or wealth between two percentiles. When the associated percentile is of the form 'pX', intermediary average returns the average between percentile pX and the next consecutive percentile. When the associated percentile is of the form 'pXpY', the variable returns the average between percentiles pX and pY.
longpop: The base unit is the individual (rather than the household) but resources are split equally within couples.
longage: The population is comprised of individuals over age 20.
source: Blanchet, Chancel and Gethin (2020), “Why is Europe less Unequal than the United States?”
method: Summary of data construction by year (see source for details): 1980: extrapolated distribution, 1981-1985: interpolated survey + concept correction + tax data, 1986: survey + concept correction + tax data, 1987-1990: interpolated survey + concept correction + tax data, 1991: survey + concept correction + tax data, 1992-1993: interpolated survey + concept correction + tax data, 1994-1995: survey + concept correction + tax data, 1996-1998: interpolated survey + concept correction + tax data, 1999: survey + concept correction + tax data, 2000-2003: interpolated survey + concept correction + tax data, 2004: survey + tax data, 2005: interpolated survey + tax data, 2006-2014: survey + tax data, 2015: extrapolated distribution using survey data, 2016-2017: extrapolated distribution

simpledes: Fiscal income is defined as the sum of all income items reported on income tax returns, before any deduction. It includes labour income, capital income and mixed income. The concept of fiscal income varies with national tax legislations, so in order to make international comparisons it is preferable to use the concept of national income.
technicaldes: [Fiscal income ]=[Fiscal labour income ]+[Fiscal capital income ]
longtype: Average income or wealth between two percentiles. When the associated percentile is of the form 'pX', intermediary average returns the average between percentile pX and the next consecutive percentile. When the associated percentile is of the form 'pXpY', the variable returns the average between percentiles pX and pY.
longpop: The base unit is the individual (rather than the household). This is equivalent to assuming no sharing of resources within couples.
longage: The population is comprised of individuals over age 20.

method: The series are presented in two distinct columns, following the change in the definition of the tax unit between 1989 and 1990. Excludes capital gains. The series are presented in two distinct columns, following the change in the definition of the tax unit between 1989 and 1990. Tax units are: individuals aged 15+ minus married females until 1989; individuals aged 15+ from 1990. Excludes capital gains. Adults are individuals aged 15+. Excludes capital gains.

simpledes: Fiscal income is defined as the sum of all income items reported on income tax returns, before any deduction. It includes labour income, capital income and mixed income. The concept of fiscal income varies with national tax legislations, so in order to make international comparisons it is preferable to use the concept of national income.
technicaldes: [Fiscal income ]=[Fiscal labour income ]+[Fiscal capital income ]
longtype: Average income or wealth between two percentiles. When the associated percentile is of the form 'pX', intermediary average returns the average between percentile pX and the next consecutive percentile. When the associated percentile is of the form 'pXpY', the variable returns the average between percentiles pX and pY.
longpop: The base unit is the tax unit defined by national fiscal administrations to measure personal income taxes.
longage: The population is comprised of individuals over age 20.

shortname: Foreign income paid to the rest of the world

longpop: The base unit is the individual (rather than the household). This is equivalent to assuming no sharing of resources within couples.
longage: The population is comprised of individuals over age 20.

simpledes: Gross domestic product is the total value of goods and services produced by the national economy.The national economy - in the national accounts sense - includes all domestic sectors, i.e. all entities that are resident of a given country (in the sense of their economic activity), whether they belong to the private sector, the corporate sector, the governement sector.
longtype: Average income or wealth between two percentiles. When the associated percentile is of the form 'pX', intermediary average returns the average between percentile pX and the next consecutive percentile. When the associated percentile is of the form 'pXpY', the variable returns the average between percentiles pX and pY.
longpop: The base unit is the individual (rather than the household). This is equivalent to assuming no sharing of resources within couples.
longage: The population is comprised of individuals over age 20.
source: See DINA guidelines for methodological explanations. The sources used are: [URL][URL_LINK]https://wid.world/document/piketty-t-and-zucman-g-2014-capital-is-back-wealth-income-ratios-in-rich-countries-1700-2010quarterly-journal-of-economics-1293-1255-1310/[/URL_LINK][URL_TEXT]Piketty T. and Zucman G. (2014), Capital is Back: Wealth-Income Ratios in Rich Countries 1700-2010, Quarterly Journal of Economics, 129(3): 1255-1310 (series updated by the same authors)[/URL_TEXT][/URL].
method: We use the GDP level in 2015 from: [URL][URL_LINK]https://wid.world/document/piketty-t-and-zucman-g-2014-capital-is-back-wealth-income-ratios-in-rich-countries-1700-2010quarterly-journal-of-economics-1293-1255-1310/[/URL_LINK][URL_TEXT]Piketty T. and Zucman G. (2014), Capital is Back: Wealth-Income Ratios in Rich Countries 1700-2010, Quarterly Journal of Economics, 129(3): 1255-1310 (series updated by the same authors)[/URL_TEXT][/URL]. Then we cumulate growth rates from the following sources; 2019: [URL][URL_LINK]http://www.imf.org/external/pubs/ft/weo/2020/01/weodata/index.aspx/[/URL_LINK][URL_TEXT]IMF World Economic Outlook (04/2020, forecast)[/URL_TEXT][/URL]; 2016–2018: [URL][URL_LINK]http://data.worldbank.org/[/URL_LINK][URL_TEXT]World Bank[/URL_TEXT][/URL]; 1855–2014: [URL][URL_LINK]https://wid.world/document/piketty-t-and-zucman-g-2014-capital-is-back-wealth-income-ratios-in-rich-countries-1700-2010quarterly-journal-of-economics-1293-1255-1310/[/URL_LINK][URL_TEXT]Piketty T. and Zucman G. (2014), Capital is Back: Wealth-Income Ratios in Rich Countries 1700-2010, Quarterly Journal of Economics, 129(3): 1255-1310 (series updated by the same authors)[/URL_TEXT][/URL].

simpledes: Net personal wealth is  the total value of non-financial and financial assets (housing, land, deposits, bonds, equities, etc.) held by households, minus their debts. . The personal or household sector - in the national accounts sense - includes all households and private individuals (including those living in institutions), as well as unincorporated enterprises whose accounts are not separated from those of the households who own them.
technicaldes: [Net personal wealth]=[Personal non-financial assets]+[Personal financial assets]-[Personal debt]

simpledes: Net domestic product is the total value of the goods and services produced in a country, minus the value of the fixed capital used up in production (e.g. replacement of obsolete machines or maintenance of roads).The national economy - in the national accounts sense - includes all domestic sectors, i.e. all entities that are resident of a given country (in the sense of their economic activity), whether they belong to the private sector, the corporate sector, the governement sector.
technicaldes: [Net domestic product]=[Gross domestic product]-[Consumption of fixed capital of national economy]

simpledes: Net foreign income is the difference between the total value of a country's citizens and companies earned abroad, and the total value of foreign citizens and overseas companies earned in that country.The national economy - in the national accounts sense - includes all domestic sectors, i.e. all entities that are resident of a given country (in the sense of their economic activity), whether they belong to the private sector, the corporate sector, the governement sector.
technicaldes: [Net foreign income]=[Property income received from abroad]-[Property income paid abroad]+[Compensation of employees received from abroad]-[Compensation of employees paid to rest of the world]
longtype: Average income or wealth between two percentiles. When the associated percentile is of the form 'pX', intermediary average returns the average between percentile pX and the next consecutive percentile. When the associated percentile is of the form 'pXpY', the variable returns the average between percentiles pX and pY.
longpop: The base unit is the individual (rather than the household). This is equivalent to assuming no sharing of resources within couples.
longage: The population is comprised of individuals of all ages.
source: See DINA guidelines for methodological explanations. The sources used are: [URL][URL_LINK]http://wid.world/document/revised-extended-national-wealth-series-australia-canada-france-germany-italy-japan-uk-usa-wid-world-technical-note-2017-23/[/URL_LINK][URL_TEXT]Piketty, Thomas; Zucman, Gabriel (2014).Capital is back: Wealth-Income ratios in Rich Countries 1700-2010. Series updated by Luis Bauluz.[/URL_TEXT][/URL]; [URL][URL_LINK]https://stats.oecd.org/Index.aspx?DataSetCode=SNA_TABLE14A[/URL_LINK][URL_TEXT]OECD[/URL_TEXT][/URL].
method: WID.world estimations as a proportion of GDP based on the following; 2019: extrapolated from last available year; 2016–2018: [URL][URL_LINK]https://stats.oecd.org/Index.aspx?DataSetCode=SNA_TABLE14A[/URL_LINK][URL_TEXT]OECD[/URL_TEXT][/URL]; 1855–2015: [URL][URL_LINK]http://wid.world/document/revised-extended-national-wealth-series-australia-canada-france-germany-italy-japan-uk-usa-wid-world-technical-note-2017-23/[/URL_LINK][URL_TEXT]Piketty, Thomas; Zucman, Gabriel (2014).Capital is back: Wealth-Income ratios in Rich Countries 1700-2010. Series updated by Luis Bauluz.[/URL_TEXT][/URL]. These estimates are then anchored to GDP (see GDP variable for details).

simpledes: National income aims to measure the total income available to the residents of a given country. It is equal to the gross domestic product (the total value of goods and services produced on the territory of a given country during a given year), minus fixed capital used in production processes (e.g. replacement of obsolete machines or maintenance of roads) plus the net foreign income earned by residents in the rest of the world.// National income has many limitations, however it is the only income concept that has an internationally agreed definition (established by the United Nations System of National Accounts, see SNA 2008). We thus use it as our reference concept (after corrections to include income hidden in tax havens). // The national economy - in the national accounts sense - includes all domestic sectors, i.e. all entities that are resident of a given country (in the sense of their economic activity), whether they belong to the private sector, the corporate sector, the governement sector.
technicaldes: [National income]=[Net domestic product]+[Net foreign income]
longtype: Average income or wealth between two percentiles. When the associated percentile is of the form 'pX', intermediary average returns the average between percentile pX and the next consecutive percentile. When the associated percentile is of the form 'pXpY', the variable returns the average between percentiles pX and pY.
longpop: The base unit is the individual (rather than the household). This is equivalent to assuming no sharing of resources within couples.
longage: The population is comprised of individuals over age 20.
source: See DINA guidelines for methodological explanations.
method: WID.world estimations as a proportion of GDP based on the following; 1855–2019: estimated from other components. These estimates are then anchored to GDP (see GDP variable for details).

method: WID.world estimations as a proportion of GDP based on the following; 1995–2018: [URL][URL_LINK]https://stats.oecd.org/Index.aspx?DataSetCode=SNA_TABLE14A[/URL_LINK][URL_TEXT]OECD[/URL_TEXT][/URL]. These estimates are then anchored to GDP (see GDP variable for details).

simpledes: National agricultural land is agricultural land owned by the national economy. Agricultural land is defined as land devoted to agriculture measured at their market value. The national economy - in the national accounts sense - includes all domestic sectors, i.e. all entities that are resident of a given country (in the sense of their economic activity), whether they belong to the private sector, the corporate sector, the governement sector.
longtype: Average income or wealth between two percentiles. When the associated percentile is of the form 'pX', intermediary average returns the average between percentile pX and the next consecutive percentile. When the associated percentile is of the form 'pXpY', the variable returns the average between percentiles pX and pY.
longpop: The base unit is the individual (rather than the household). This is equivalent to assuming no sharing of resources within couples.
longage: The population is comprised of individuals over age 20.

simpledes: National other domestic capital is non-financial assets owned by the national economy except housing assets and agricultural land (machinery, equipment, etc.). Non-financial assets are defined as assets with a physical value (real estate, machinery, equipment, etc.) measured at their market value.  The national economy - in the national accounts sense - includes all domestic sectors, i.e. all entities that are resident of a given country (in the sense of their economic activity), whether they belong to the private sector, the corporate sector, the governement sector.
longtype: Average income or wealth between two percentiles. When the associated percentile is of the form 'pX', intermediary average returns the average between percentile pX and the next consecutive percentile. When the associated percentile is of the form 'pXpY', the variable returns the average between percentiles pX and pY.
longpop: The base unit is the individual (rather than the household). This is equivalent to assuming no sharing of resources within couples.
longage: The population is comprised of individuals of all ages.
source: [URL][URL_LINK]http://wid.world/document/revised-extended-national-wealth-series-australia-canada-france-germany-italy-japan-uk-usa-wid-world-technical-note-2017-23/[/URL_LINK][URL_TEXT]Piketty, Thomas; Zucman, Gabriel (2014).Capital is back: Wealth-Income ratios in Rich Countries 1700-2010. Series updated by Luis Bauluz.[/URL_TEXT][/URL];

shortname: Property income paid from the rest of the world

technicaldes: [Capital income paid to the rest of the world]=[Foreign direct investment income paid to the rest of the world]+[Portfolio and other income paid to the rest of the world]

simpledes: Pre-tax national income  is the sum of all pre-tax personal income flows accruing to the owners of the production factors, labor and capital, before taking into account the operation of the tax/transfer system, but after taking into account the operation of pension system. The central difference between personal factor income and pre-tax income is the treatment of pensions, which are counted on a contribution basis by factor income and on a distribution basis by pre-tax income.
technicaldes: Pre-tax national income =Pre-tax labor income [total pre-tax income ranking]+Pre-tax capital income [total pre-tax income ranking]
longtype: Average income or wealth between two percentiles. When the associated percentile is of the form 'pX', intermediary average returns the average between percentile pX and the next consecutive percentile. When the associated percentile is of the form 'pXpY', the variable returns the average between percentiles pX and pY.
longpop: The base unit is the individual (rather than the household) but resources are split equally within couples.
longage: The population is comprised of individuals over age 20.
source: Blanchet, Chancel and Gethin (2020), “Why is Europe less Unequal than the United States?”; [URL][URL_LINK]https://wid.world/document/atkinson-anthony-b-2007-the-distribution-of-top-incomes-in-the-united-kingdom-1908-2000-in-atkinson-a-b-and-piketty-t-editors-top-incomes-over-the-twentieth-century-a-contrast-betwe/[/URL_LINK][URL_TEXT]Atkinson, Anthony B. (2007). The Distribution of Top Incomes in the United Kingdom 1908-2000; in Atkinson, A. B. and Piketty, T. (editors) Top Incomes over the Twentieth Century. (2012). method: Summary of data construction by year (see source for details): 1980: extrapolated distribution, 1981-1985: interpolated survey + concept correction + tax data, 1986: survey + concept correction + tax data, 1987-1990: interpolated survey + concept correction + tax data, 1991: survey + concept correction + tax data, 1992-1993: interpolated survey + concept correction + tax data, 1994-1995: survey + concept correction + tax data, 1996-1998: interpolated survey + concept correction + tax data, 1999: survey + concept correction + tax data, 2000-2003: interpolated survey + concept correction + tax data, 2004: survey + tax data, 2005: interpolated survey + tax data, 2006-2014: survey + tax data, 2015: extrapolated distribution using survey data, 2016-2017: extrapolated distribution. Before 1980, pretax income shares retropolated based on fiscal income: see source.

simpledes: Private agricultural land is agricultural land held by private owners (households and foundations). The private sector - in the national accounts sense - includes the personal sector (households) and the non-profit sector (foundations, religious organizations, etc.). In certain countries, availables sources do not allow to decompose the wealth owned by each of these two sub-sectors, and we only provide total net private wealth.
technicaldes: [Private agricultural land]=[Personal agricultural land]+[Non-profit agricultural land]

simpledes: Private business assets include agricultural land and other domestic material and immaterial non-financial assets (machinery, equipment, patents, etc.) held by private owners (households and foundations). The private sector - in the national accounts sense - includes the personal sector (households) and the non-profit sector (foundations, religious organizations, etc.). In certain countries, availables sources do not allow to decompose the wealth owned by each of these two sub-sectors, and we only provide total net private wealth.
technicaldes: [Private business assets]=[Private agricultural land]+[Other domestic private capital]+[Private natural capital]
longtype: Average income or wealth between two percentiles. When the associated percentile is of the form 'pX', intermediary average returns the average between percentile pX and the next consecutive percentile. When the associated percentile is of the form 'pXpY', the variable returns the average between percentiles pX and pY.
longpop: The base unit is the individual (rather than the household). This is equivalent to assuming no sharing of resources within couples.
longage: The population is comprised of individuals over age 20.
source: [URL][URL_LINK]http://wid.world/document/revised-extended-national-wealth-series-australia-canada-france-germany-italy-japan-uk-usa-wid-world-technical-note-2017-23/[/URL_LINK][URL_TEXT]Piketty, Thomas; Zucman, Gabriel (2014).Capital is back: Wealth-Income ratios in Rich Countries 1700-2010. Series updated by Luis Bauluz.[/URL_TEXT][/URL];

simpledes: Net private wealth is  the total value of non-financial and financial assets (housing, land, deposits, bonds, equities of corporations, etc.) held by private owners (households and foundations), minus their debts.  The private sector - in the national accounts sense - includes the personal sector (households) and the non-profit sector (foundations, religious organizations, etc.). In certain countries, availables sources do not allow to decompose the wealth owned by each of these two sub-sectors, and we only provide total net private wealth.
technicaldes: [Net private wealth]=[Private non-financial assets]+[Private financial assets]-[Private debt]
longtype: Average income or wealth between two percentiles. When the associated percentile is of the form 'pX', intermediary average returns the average between percentile pX and the next consecutive percentile. When the associated percentile is of the form 'pXpY', the variable returns the average between percentiles pX and pY.
longpop: The base unit is the individual (rather than the household). This is equivalent to assuming no sharing of resources within couples.
longage: The population is comprised of individuals over age 20.
source: Piketty T. and Zucman G. (2014), Capital is Back: Wealth-Income Ratios in Rich Countries 1700-2010, Quarterly Journal of Economics, 129(3): 1255-1310. Series updated by the same authors.;

In certain countries, availables sources do not allow to decompose the wealth owned by each of these two sub-sectors, and we only provide total net private wealth.

When the associated percentile is of the form 'pXpY', the variable returns the average between percentiles pX and pY.
longpop: The base unit is the individual (rather than the household). This is equivalent to assuming no sharing of resources within couples.
longage: The population is comprised of individuals of all ages.
source: [URL][URL_LINK]http://wid.world/document/revised-extended-national-wealth-series-australia-canada-france-germany-italy-japan-uk-usa-wid-world-technical-note-2017-23/[/URL_LINK][URL_TEXT]Piketty, Thomas; Zucman, Gabriel (2014).Capital is back: Wealth-Income ratios in Rich Countries 1700-2010. Series updated by Luis Bauluz.[/URL_TEXT][/URL];

simpledes: Private pension funds & life insurance are pension funds and life insurance held by private owners (households and foundations). The private sector - in the national accounts sense - includes the personal sector (households) and the non-profit sector (foundations, religious organizations, etc.). In certain countries, availables sources do not allow to decompose the wealth owned by each of these two sub-sectors, and we only provide total net private wealth.
technicaldes: [Private pension funds & life insurance]=[Personal pension funds & life insurance]+[Non-profit pension funds & life insurance]

simpledes: Post-tax private income corresponds to all sources of incomes, net of taxes, received by individuals and which can be individualized (this excludes social transfers in kind, collective consumption expenditure and government deficit).
technicaldes: Post-tax disposable income=Pre-tax income-Taxes on production (net)-Current taxes on income and wealth+Social assistance benefits in cash
longtype: The beta coefficient corresponds to the inverted Pareto-Lorenz coefficient. It is equal to mean income over a certain income level divided by this level. A coefficient b=2=200% for an income level 100 000 EUR means that the average income above 100 000 EUR is 200 000 EUR, a coefficient of 3 or 300% at income level 1 000 000 EUR means that the average income level above 1 000 000 EUR in a given population is 3 000 000 EUR.
longpop: The base unit is the individual (rather than the household) but resources are split equally within couples.
longage: The population is comprised of individuals over age 20.
source: Blanchet, Chancel and Gethin (2020), “Why is Europe less Unequal than the United States?”
method: Summary of data construction by year (see source for details): 1980: extrapolated distribution, 1981-1985: interpolated survey + concept correction + tax data, 1986: survey + concept correction + tax data, 1987-1990: interpolated survey + concept correction + tax data, 1991: survey + concept correction + tax data, 1992-1993: interpolated survey + concept correction + tax data, 1994-1995: survey + concept correction + tax data, 1996-1998: interpolated survey + concept correction + tax data, 1999: survey + concept correction + tax data, 2000-2003: interpolated survey + concept correction + tax data, 2004: survey + tax data, 2005: interpolated survey + tax data, 2006-2014: survey + tax data, 2015: extrapolated distribution using survey data, 2016-2017: extrapolated distribution

simpledes: Post-tax national income is the sum of primary incomes over all sectors (private and public), minus taxes.
technicaldes: [Post-tax national income]=[Post-tax disposable income]+[Public spending]
longtype: The beta coefficient corresponds to the inverted Pareto-Lorenz coefficient. It is equal to mean income over a certain income level divided by this level. simpledes: Fiscal income is defined as the sum of all income items reported on income tax returns, before any deduction. It includes labour income, capital income and mixed income. The concept of fiscal income varies with national tax legislations, so in order to make international comparisons it is preferable to use the concept of national income.
technicaldes: [Fiscal income ]=[Fiscal labour income ]+[Fiscal capital income ]
longtype: The beta coefficient corresponds to the inverted Pareto-Lorenz coefficient. It is equal to mean income over a certain income level divided by this level. method: The series are presented in two distinct columns, following the change in the definition of the tax unit between 1989 and 1990. Excludes capital gains. The series are presented in two distinct columns, following the change in the definition of the tax unit between 1989 and 1990. Tax units are: individuals aged 15+ minus married females until 1989; individuals aged 15+ from 1990. Excludes capital gains. Adults are individuals aged 15+. Excludes capital gains.

simpledes: Pre-tax national income  is the sum of all pre-tax personal income flows accruing to the owners of the production factors, labor and capital, before taking into account the operation of the tax/transfer system, but after taking into account the operation of pension system. The central difference between personal factor income and pre-tax income is the treatment of pensions, which are counted on a contribution basis by factor income and on a distribution basis by pre-tax income.
technicaldes: Pre-tax national income =Pre-tax labor income [total pre-tax income ranking]+Pre-tax capital income [total pre-tax income ranking]
longtype: The beta coefficient corresponds to the inverted Pareto-Lorenz coefficient. It is equal to mean income over a certain income level divided by this level. A coefficient b=2=200% for an income level 100 000 EUR means that the average income above 100 000 EUR is 200 000 EUR, a coefficient of 3 or 300% at income level 1 000 000 EUR means that the average income level above 1 000 000 EUR in a given population is 3 000 000 EUR.
longpop: The base unit is the individual (rather than the household) but resources are split equally within couples.
longage: The population is comprised of individuals over age 20.

longtype: The Gini coefficient is a measure of statistical dispersion. A coefficient of zero expresses perfect equality between individuals. A coefficient of one expresses maximal inequality, where only one person owns all the income or wealth of the economy.

method: The series are presented in two distinct columns, following the change in the definition of the tax unit between 1989 and 1990. Excludes capital gains. The series are presented in two distinct columns, following the change in the definition of the tax unit between 1989 and 1990. Tax units are: individuals aged 15+ minus married females until 1989; individuals aged 15+ from 1990. Excludes capital gains. Adults are individuals aged 15+. Excludes capital gains.

simpledes: Pre-tax national income  is the sum of all pre-tax personal income flows accruing to the owners of the production factors, labor and capital, before taking into account the operation of the tax/transfer system, but after taking into account the operation of pension system. The central difference between personal factor income and pre-tax income is the treatment of pensions, which are counted on a contribution basis by factor income and on a distribution basis by pre-tax income.
technicaldes: Pre-tax national income =Pre-tax labor income [total pre-tax income ranking]+Pre-tax capital income [total pre-tax income ranking]
longtype: The Gini coefficient is a measure of statistical dispersion. A coefficient of zero expresses perfect equality between individuals. A coefficient of one expresses maximal inequality, where only one person owns all the income or wealth of the economy.
longpop: The base unit is the individual (rather than the household) but resources are split equally within couples.
longage: The population is comprised of individuals over age 20.

method: Summary of data construction by year (see source for details): 1980: extrapolated distribution, 1981-1985: interpolated survey + concept correction + tax data, 1986: survey + concept correction + tax data, 1987-1990: interpolated survey + concept correction + tax data, 1991: survey + concept correction + tax data, 1992-1993: interpolated survey + concept correction + tax data, 1994-1995: survey + concept correction + tax data, 1996-1998: interpolated survey + concept correction + tax data, 1999: survey + concept correction + tax data, 2000-2003: interpolated survey + concept correction + tax data, 2004: survey + tax data, 2005: interpolated survey + tax data, 2006-2014: survey + tax data, 2015: extrapolated distribution using survey data, 2016-2017: extrapolated distribution. Before 1980, pretax income shares retropolated based on fiscal income: see source.

simpledes: Tobin's Q is the ratio between the market value of corporations (stock market capitalisation) and the book value of corporations (assets minus debt). The corporate sector - in the national accounts sense - includes all financial and non-financial corporations with an economic activity in a given country, whatever their legal status (with the exceptions of unincorporated enterprises included in the personal sector).
longtype: Indices
longpop: The base unit is the individual (rather than the household). This is equivalent to assuming no sharing of resources within couples.
longage: The population is comprised of individuals of all ages.
source: Piketty T. and Zucman G. (2014), Capital is Back: Wealth-Income Ratios in Rich Countries 1700-2010, Quarterly Journal of Economics, 129(3): 1255-1310. Series updated by the same authors.;

method: We cumulate inflation rates from the following sources; 1855-2015: price index provided by the researchers (see source); 2016-2018: GDP deflator from the World Bank; 2019: CPI from the World Bank.

method: WID.world estimations as a proportion of GDP based on the following; 1995–2018: [URL][URL_LINK]https://stats.oecd.org/Index.aspx?DataSetCode=SNA_TABLE14A[/URL_LINK][URL_TEXT]OECD[/URL_TEXT][/URL]; 1987–1994: [URL][URL_LINK]http://data.imf.org/BOP[/URL_LINK][URL_TEXT]IMF Balance of Payments Statistics[/URL_TEXT][/URL]; 1984–1986: [URL][URL_LINK]http://data.un.org/Explorer.aspx[/URL_LINK][URL_TEXT]UN SNA (1968)[/URL_TEXT][/URL]; 1970–1983: [URL][URL_LINK]http://data.imf.org/BOP[/URL_LINK][URL_TEXT]IMF Balance of Payments Statistics[/URL_TEXT][/URL]; 1963–1969: [URL][URL_LINK]http://data.un.org/Explorer.aspx[/URL_LINK][URL_TEXT]UN SNA (1968)[/URL_TEXT][/URL]. These estimates are then anchored to GDP (see GDP variable for details).

simpledes: Consumption of fixed capital of national economy is the decline in total value of fixed assets (e.g. roads, machines) which are owned and used by a producer. In other words, the amounts required to maintain the quality of fixed assets from a year to another. The decline in  value is a result of physical deterioration, normal obsolescence or normal accidental damage.The national economy - in the national accounts sense - includes all domestic sectors, i.e. all entities that are resident of a given country (in the sense of their economic activity), whether they belong to the private sector, the corporate sector, the governement sector.
longtype: Macroeconomic variable (i.e. corresponding to national economy rather than to a given group of individuals). The associated percentile is of the form 'pall'.
longpop: The base unit is the individual (rather than the household). This is equivalent to assuming no sharing of resources within couples.
longage: The population is comprised of individuals of all ages.
source: See DINA guidelines for methodological explanations.
method: WID.world estimations as a proportion of GDP based on the following; 1855–2019: imputed value. These estimates are then anchored to GDP (see GDP variable for details).

simpledes: Corporate agricultural land is agricultural land owned by the corporate sector (companies). Agricultural land is defined as land devoted to agriculture. The corporate sector - in the national accounts sense - includes all financial and non-financial corporations with an economic activity in a given country, whatever their legal status (with the exceptions of unincorporated enterprises included in the personal sector).
longtype: Macroeconomic variable (i.e. corresponding to national economy rather than to a given group of individuals). The associated percentile is of the form 'pall'.
longpop: The base unit is the individual (rather than the household). This is equivalent to assuming no sharing of resources within couples.
longage: The population is comprised of individuals of all ages.

Series updated by Luis Bauluz.[/URL_TEXT][/URL];

shortname: Corporate equity, fund shares & offshore wealth
simpledes: Corporate equity, fund shares & offshore wealth are company stocks, fund shares and wealth outside of one's residence country owned by the corporate sector (companies). The corporate sector - in the national accounts sense - includes all financial and non-financial corporations with an economic activity in a given country, whatever their legal status (with the exceptions of unincorporated enterprises included in the personal sector).
technicaldes: [Corporate equity, fund shares & offshore wealth]=[Corporate equities]+[Corporate offshore wealth]
longtype: Macroeconomic variable (i.e. corresponding to national economy rather than to a given group of individuals). The associated percentile is of the form 'pall'.
longpop: The base unit is the individual (rather than the household). This is equivalent to assuming no sharing of resources within couples.
longage: The population is comprised of individuals of all ages.

simpledes: Corporate financial assets excluding cash are financial assets except cash and bank deposits owned by the corporate sector (companies). technicaldes: [Corporate financial assets excluding cash]=[Corporate currency & deposits]-[Corporate equity, fund shares & offshore wealth]
longtype: Macroeconomic variable (i.e. corresponding to national economy rather than to a given group of individuals). The associated percentile is of the form 'pall'.

simpledes: Corporate financial assets are intangible assets whose value is derived from a contractual claim (bank deposits, bonds, and stocks) owned by the corporate sector (companies). The corporate sector - in the national accounts sense - includes all financial and non-financial corporations with an economic activity in a given country, whatever their legal status (with the exceptions of unincorporated enterprises included in the personal sector).
technicaldes: [Corporate financial assets]=[Corporate currency, deposits, bonds & loans]+[Corporate equity, fund shares & offshore wealth]+[Corporate pension funds & life insurance]
longtype: Macroeconomic variable (i.e. corresponding to national economy rather than to a given group of individuals). The associated percentile is of the form 'pall'.

simpledes: Fiscal income is defined as the sum of all income items reported on income tax returns, before any deduction. It includes labour income, capital income and mixed income. The concept of fiscal income varies with national tax legislations, so in order to make international comparisons it is preferable to use the concept of national income.
technicaldes: [Fiscal income ]=[Fiscal labour income ]+[Fiscal capital income ]

method: The series are presented in two distinct columns, following the change in the definition of the tax unit between 1989 and 1990. Excludes capital gains. simpledes: Gross domestic product is the total value of goods and services produced by the national economy.The national economy - in the national accounts sense - includes all domestic sectors, i.e. all entities that are resident of a given country (in the sense of their economic activity), whether they belong to the private sector, the corporate sector, the governement sector.
longtype: Macroeconomic variable (i.e. corresponding to national economy rather than to a given group of individuals). The associated percentile is of the form 'pall'.
longpop: The base unit is the individual (rather than the household). This is equivalent to assuming no sharing of resources within couples.
longage: The population is comprised of individuals of all ages.
source: See DINA guidelines for methodological explanations. The sources used are: [URL][URL_LINK]https://wid.world/document/piketty-t-and-zucman-g-2014-capital-is-back-wealth-income-ratios-in-rich-countries-1700-2010quarterly-journal-of-economics-1293-1255-1310/[/URL_LINK][URL_TEXT]Piketty T. and Zucman G. (2014), Capital is Back: Wealth-Income Ratios in Rich Countries 1700-2010, Quarterly Journal of Economics, 129(3): 1255-1310 (series updated by the same authors)[/URL_TEXT][/URL].
method: We use the GDP level in 2015 from: [URL][URL_LINK]https://wid.world/document/piketty-t-and-zucman-g-2014-capital-is-back-wealth-income-ratios-in-rich-countries-1700-2010quarterly-journal-of-economics-1293-1255-1310/[/URL_LINK][URL_TEXT]Piketty T. and Zucman G. (2014), Capital is Back: Wealth-Income Ratios in Rich Countries 1700-2010, Quarterly Journal of Economics, 129(3): 1255-1310 (series updated by the same authors)[/URL_TEXT][/URL]. Then we cumulate growth rates from the following sources; 2019: [URL][URL_LINK]http://www.imf.org/external/pubs/ft/weo/2020/01/weodata/index.aspx/[/URL_LINK][URL_TEXT]IMF World Economic Outlook (04/2020, forecast)[/URL_TEXT][/URL]; 2016–2018: [URL][URL_LINK]http://data.worldbank.org/[/URL_LINK][URL_TEXT]World Bank[/URL_TEXT][/URL]; 1855–2014: [URL][URL_LINK]https://wid.world/document/piketty-t-and-zucman-g-2014-capital-is-back-wealth-income-ratios-in-rich-countries-1700-2010quarterly-journal-of-economics-1293-1255-1310/[/URL_LINK][URL_TEXT]Piketty T. and Zucman G. (2014), Capital is Back: Wealth-Income Ratios in Rich Countries 1700-2010, Quarterly Journal of Economics, 129(3): 1255-1310 (series updated by the same authors)[/URL_TEXT][/URL].

simpledes: Government agricultural land is agricultural land owned by the general government sector (central government, state government, local government, and social security funds). Agricultural land is defined as land devoted to agriculture. The government sector - in the national accounts - includes are national, regional local governement, social security administrations, and more generally all entities relying primarily upon public financing (taxes, contributions, and other compulsory payments).
longtype: Macroeconomic variable (i.e. corresponding to national economy rather than to a given group of individuals). The associated percentile is of the form 'pall'.
longpop: The base unit is the individual (rather than the household). This is equivalent to assuming no sharing of resources within couples.
longage: The population is comprised of individuals of all ages.
source: [URL][URL_LINK]http://wid.world/document/revised-extended-national-wealth-series-australia-canada-france-germany-italy-japan-uk-usa-wid-world-technical-note-2017-23/[/URL_LINK][URL_TEXT]Piketty, Thomas; Zucman, Gabriel (2014).Capital is back: Wealth-Income ratios in Rich Countries 1700-2010. Series updated by Luis Bauluz.[/URL_TEXT][/URL];

simpledes: Net public wealth is the total value of assets (cash, housing, bonds, equities, etc.) owned by the general government sector (central government, state government, local government, and social security funds), minus its debts. technicaldes: [Net public wealth]=[Government non-financial assets]+[Government financial assets]-[Government debt]

simpledes: Government other domestic capital is non-financial assets owned by the general government sector (central government, state government, local government, and social security funds) except housing assets and agricultural land (machinery, equipment, etc.). The government sector - in the national accounts - includes are national, regional local governement, social security administrations, and more generally all entities relying primarily upon public financing (taxes, contributions, and other compulsory payments).
longtype: Macroeconomic variable (i.e. corresponding to national economy rather than to a given group of individuals). The associated percentile is of the form 'pall'.
longpop: The base unit is the individual (rather than the household). This is equivalent to assuming no sharing of resources within couples.
longage: The population is comprised of individuals of all ages.
source: [URL][URL_LINK]http://wid.world/document/revised-extended-national-wealth-series-australia-canada-france-germany-italy-japan-uk-usa-wid-world-technical-note-2017-23/[/URL_LINK][URL_TEXT]Piketty, Thomas; Zucman, Gabriel (2014).Capital is back: Wealth-Income ratios in Rich Countries 1700-2010. Series updated by Luis Bauluz.[/URL_TEXT][/URL];

simpledes: Net domestic product is the total value of the goods and services produced in a country, minus the value of the fixed capital used up in production (e.g. replacement of obsolete machines or maintenance of roads).The national economy - in the national accounts sense - includes all domestic sectors, i.e. all entities that are resident of a given country (in the sense of their economic activity), whether they belong to the private sector, the corporate sector, the governement sector.
technicaldes: [Net domestic product]=[Gross domestic product]-[Consumption of fixed capital of national economy]
longtype: Macroeconomic variable (i.e. corresponding to national economy rather than to a given group of individuals). The associated percentile is of the form 'pall'.
longpop: The base unit is the individual (rather than the household). This is equivalent to assuming no sharing of resources within couples.
longage: The population is comprised of individuals of all ages.
source: See DINA guidelines for methodological explanations.
method: WID.world estimations as a proportion of GDP based on the following; 1855–2019: estimated from other components. These estimates are then anchored to GDP (see GDP variable for details).

simpledes: Net foreign income is the difference between the total value of a country's citizens and companies earned abroad, and the total value of foreign citizens and overseas companies earned in that country.The national economy - in the national accounts sense - includes all domestic sectors, i.e. all entities that are resident of a given country (in the sense of their economic activity), whether they belong to the private sector, the corporate sector, the governement sector.
technicaldes: [Net foreign income]=[Property income received from abroad]-[Property income paid abroad]+[Compensation of employees received from abroad]-[Compensation of employees paid to rest of the world]
longtype: Macroeconomic variable (i.e. corresponding to national economy rather than to a given group of individuals). The associated percentile is of the form 'pall'.
longpop: The base unit is the individual (rather than the household). This is equivalent to assuming no sharing of resources within couples.
longage: The population is comprised of individuals of all ages.

Series updated by Luis Bauluz.[/URL_TEXT][/URL]. These estimates are then anchored to GDP (see GDP variable for details).

simpledes: National income aims to measure the total income available to the residents of a given country. It is equal to the gross domestic product (the total value of goods and services produced on the territory of a given country during a given year), minus fixed capital used in production processes (e.g. replacement of obsolete machines or maintenance of roads) plus the net foreign income earned by residents in the rest of the world.// National income has many limitations, however it is the only income concept that has an internationally agreed definition (established by the United Nations System of National Accounts, see SNA 2008). We thus use it as our reference concept (after corrections to include income hidden in tax havens). // The national economy - in the national accounts sense - includes all domestic sectors, i.e. all entities that are resident of a given country (in the sense of their economic activity), whether they belong to the private sector, the corporate sector, the governement sector.
technicaldes: [National income]=[Net domestic product]+[Net foreign income]
longtype: Macroeconomic variable (i.e. corresponding to national economy rather than to a given group of individuals). The associated percentile is of the form 'pall'.
longpop: The base unit is the individual (rather than the household). This is equivalent to assuming no sharing of resources within couples.
longage: The population is comprised of individuals of all ages.
source: See DINA guidelines for methodological explanations.
method: WID.world estimations as a proportion of GDP based on the following; 1855–2019: estimated from other components. These estimates are then anchored to GDP (see GDP variable for details).

simpledes: National agricultural land is agricultural land owned by the national economy. Agricultural land is defined as land devoted to agriculture measured at their market value. The national economy - in the national accounts sense - includes all domestic sectors, i.e. all entities that are resident of a given country (in the sense of their economic activity), whether they belong to the private sector, the corporate sector, the governement sector.
longtype: Macroeconomic variable (i.e. corresponding to national economy rather than to a given group of individuals). The associated percentile is of the form 'pall'.
longpop: The base unit is the individual (rather than the household). This is equivalent to assuming no sharing of resources within couples.
longage: The population is comprised of individuals of all ages.

Series updated by Luis Bauluz.[/URL_TEXT][/URL];

simpledes: Book-value national wealth is the sum of value of assets according to the books (balance sheets) on which they are carried. It is the difference between net national wealth and national net corporate wealth. The national economy - in the national accounts sense - includes all domestic sectors, i.e. all entities that are resident of a given country (in the sense of their economic activity), whether they belong to the private sector, the corporate sector, the governement sector.
technicaldes: [Book-value national wealth]=[National non-financial assets (book value value)]+[Net foreign assets]
longtype: Macroeconomic variable (i.e. corresponding to national economy rather than to a given group of individuals). The associated percentile is of the form 'pall'.
longpop: The base unit is the individual (rather than the household). This is equivalent to assuming no sharing of resources within couples.
longage: The population is comprised of individuals of all ages.
source: [URL][URL_LINK]http://wid.world/document/revised-extended-national-wealth-series-australia-canada-france-germany-italy-japan-uk-usa-wid-world-technical-note-2017-23/[/URL_LINK][URL_TEXT]Piketty, Thomas; Zucman, Gabriel (2014).Capital is back: Wealth-Income ratios in Rich Countries 1700-2010. Series updated by Luis Bauluz.[/URL_TEXT][/URL];

shortname: National business and other non-financial assets
simpledes: National business and other non-financial assets are agricultural land and other domestic non-financial assets owned by the national economy and measured at their market value.  The national economy - in the national accounts sense - includes all domestic sectors, i.e. all entities that are resident of a given country (in the sense of their economic activity), whether they belong to the private sector, the corporate sector, the governement sector.
technicaldes: [National business and other non-financial assets]=[National other domestic capital]+[National agricultural land]+[National natural capital]
longtype: Macroeconomic variable (i.e. corresponding to national economy rather than to a given group of individuals). The associated percentile is of the form 'pall'.
longpop: The base unit is the individual (rather than the household). This is equivalent to assuming no sharing of resources within couples.
longage: The population is comprised of individuals of all ages.

Series updated by Luis Bauluz.[/URL_TEXT][/URL];

simpledes: Domestic financial liabilities of the national economy correspond to the sum of all financial liabilities of the private, government and corporate sectors.

simpledes: Net national wealth is the total value of assets (cash, housing, bonds, equities, etc.) owned by the national economy, minus its debts. The national economy - in the national accounts sense - includes all domestic sectors, i.e. all entities that are resident of a given country (in the sense of their economic activity), whether they belong to the private sector, the corporate sector, the governement sector.
technicaldes: [Market-value national wealth ]=[National non-financial assets (market value)]+[Net foreign assets]
longtype: Macroeconomic variable (i.e. corresponding to national economy rather than to a given group of individuals). The associated percentile is of the form 'pall'.
longpop: The base unit is the individual (rather than the household). This is equivalent to assuming no sharing of resources within couples.
longage: The population is comprised of individuals of all ages.

simpledes: Private agricultural land is agricultural land held by private owners (households and foundations). The private sector - in the national accounts sense - includes the personal sector (households) and the non-profit sector (foundations, religious organizations, etc.). In certain countries, availables sources do not allow to decompose the wealth owned by each of these two sub-sectors, and we only provide total net private wealth.
technicaldes: [Private agricultural land]=[Personal agricultural land]+[Non-profit agricultural land]
longtype: Macroeconomic variable (i.e. corresponding to national economy rather than to a given group of individuals). The associated percentile is of the form 'pall'.
longpop: The base unit is the individual (rather than the household). This is equivalent to assuming no sharing of resources within couples.
longage: The population is comprised of individuals of all ages.
source: [URL][URL_LINK]http://wid.world/document/revised-extended-national-wealth-series-australia-canada-france-germany-italy-japan-uk-usa-wid-world-technical-note-2017-23/[/URL_LINK][URL_TEXT]Piketty, Thomas; Zucman, Gabriel (2014).Capital is back: Wealth-Income ratios in Rich Countries 1700-2010. Series updated by Luis Bauluz.[/URL_TEXT][/URL];

simpledes: Private bonds & loans are bonds and loans held by private owners (households and foundations). The private sector - in the national accounts sense - includes the personal sector (households) and the non-profit sector (foundations, religious organizations, etc.). In certain countries, availables sources do not allow to decompose the wealth owned by each of these two sub-sectors, and we only provide total net private wealth.
technicaldes: [Private bonds & loans]=[Personal bonds & loans]+[Non-profit bonds & loans]
longtype: Macroeconomic variable (i.e. corresponding to national economy rather than to a given group of individuals). The associated percentile is of the form 'pall'.
longpop: The base unit is the individual (rather than the household). This is equivalent to assuming no sharing of resources within couples.
longage: The population is comprised of individuals of all ages.

simpledes: Private debt is debts or legal obligations held by private owners (households and foundations). The private sector - in the national accounts sense - includes the personal sector (households) and the non-profit sector (foundations, religious organizations, etc.). In certain countries, availables sources do not allow to decompose the wealth owned by each of these two sub-sectors, and we only provide total net private wealth.

longtype: Macroeconomic variable (i.e. corresponding to national economy rather than to a given group of individuals). The associated percentile is of the form 'pall'.

simpledes: Net private wealth is  the total value of non-financial and financial assets (housing, land, deposits, bonds, equities of corporations, etc.) held by private owners (households and foundations), minus their debts.  The private sector - in the national accounts sense - includes the personal sector (households) and the non-profit sector (foundations, religious organizations, etc.). In certain countries, availables sources do not allow to decompose the wealth owned by each of these two sub-sectors, and we only provide total net private wealth.
technicaldes: [Net private wealth]=[Private non-financial assets]+[Private financial assets]-[Private debt]
longtype: Macroeconomic variable (i.e. corresponding to national economy rather than to a given group of individuals). The associated percentile is of the form 'pall'.
longpop: The base unit is the individual (rather than the household). This is equivalent to assuming no sharing of resources within couples.
longage: The population is comprised of individuals of all ages.
source: Piketty T. and Zucman G. (2014), Capital is Back: Wealth-Income Ratios in Rich Countries 1700-2010, Quarterly Journal of Economics, 129(3): 1255-1310. Series updated by the same authors.;

shortname: Private equity, fund shares & offshore wealth

In certain countries, availables sources do not allow to decompose the wealth owned by each of these two sub-sectors, and we only provide total net private wealth.

longtype: Macroeconomic variable (i.e. corresponding to national economy rather than to a given group of individuals). The associated percentile is of the form 'pall'.

longtype: Macroeconomic variable (i.e. corresponding to national economy rather than to a given group of individuals). The associated percentile is of the form 'pall'.

method: WID.world estimations as a proportion of GDP based on the following; 1995–2018: [URL][URL_LINK]https://stats.oecd.org/Index.aspx?DataSetCode=SNA_TABLE14A[/URL_LINK][URL_TEXT]OECD[/URL_TEXT][/URL]; 1987–1994: [URL][URL_LINK]http://data.un.org/Explorer.aspx[/URL_LINK][URL_TEXT]UN SNA (1993)[/URL_TEXT][/URL]. These estimates are then anchored to GDP (see GDP variable for details).

longtype: Income or wealth shares. simpledes: Net personal wealth is  the total value of non-financial and financial assets (housing, land, deposits, bonds, equities, etc.) held by households, minus their debts. . The personal or household sector - in the national accounts sense - includes all households and private individuals (including those living in institutions), as well as unincorporated enterprises whose accounts are not separated from those of the households who own them.
technicaldes: [Net personal wealth]=[Personal non-financial assets]+[Personal financial assets]-[Personal debt]
longtype: Income or wealth shares. When the associated percentile is of the form 'pX', the raw data stores the share of total income or wealth detained by all the population between threshold pX and the top of the distribution. When the associated percentile is of the form 'pXpY', the raw data stores the share of the population between thresholds pX and pY.
longpop: The base unit is the individual (rather than the household). This is equivalent to assuming no sharing of resources within couples.
longage: The population is comprised of individuals over age 20.
source: [URL][URL_LINK]http://wid.world/document/f-alvaredo-b-atkinson-s-morelli-2017-top-wealth-shares-uk-century-wid-world-working-paper/[/URL_LINK][URL_TEXT]Alvaredo, Facundo; Atkinson, Anthony B. and Morelli, Salvatore (2016). Top Wealth Shares in the UK over more than a century[/URL_TEXT][/URL];

simpledes: Pre-tax national income  is the sum of all pre-tax personal income flows accruing to the owners of the production factors, labor and capital, before taking into account the operation of the tax/transfer system, but after taking into account the operation of pension system. The central difference between personal factor income and pre-tax income is the treatment of pensions, which are counted on a contribution basis by factor income and on a distribution basis by pre-tax income.
technicaldes: Pre-tax national income =Pre-tax labor income [total pre-tax income ranking]+Pre-tax capital income [total pre-tax income ranking]
longtype: Income or wealth shares. When the associated percentile is of the form 'pX', the raw data stores the share of total income or wealth detained by all the population between threshold pX and the top of the distribution. When the associated percentile is of the form 'pXpY', the raw data stores the share of the population between thresholds pX and pY.
longpop: The base unit is the individual (rather than the household) but resources are split equally within couples.
longage: The population is comprised of individuals over age 20.

method: Summary of data construction by year (see source for details): 1980: extrapolated distribution, 1981-1985: interpolated survey + concept correction + tax data, 1986: survey + concept correction + tax data, 1987-1990: interpolated survey + concept correction + tax data, 1991: survey + concept correction + tax data, 1992-1993: interpolated survey + concept correction + tax data, 1994-1995: survey + concept correction + tax data, 1996-1998: interpolated survey + concept correction + tax data, 1999: survey + concept correction + tax data, 2000-2003: interpolated survey + concept correction + tax data, 2004: survey + tax data, 2005: interpolated survey + tax data, 2006-2014: survey + tax data, 2015: extrapolated distribution using survey data, 2016-2017: extrapolated distribution. Before 1980, pretax income shares retropolated based on fiscal income: see source.

shortname: Pre-tax capital income [total pre-tax income ranking]
simpledes: Pre-tax capital income  is the sum of all pre-tax personal income flows accruing to the individual owners of capital as a production factor, before taking into account the operation of the tax/transfer system, but after taking into account the operation of pension system. The central difference between personal factor income and pre-tax income is the treatment of pensions, which are counted on a contribution basis by factor income and on a distribution basis by pre-tax income.
technicaldes: Pre-tax capital income [total pre-tax income ranking]=Housing asset income+Equity asset income+Interest income+Pensions and social insurance income (capital share)-Interest payments
longtype: Percentile (i.e. threshold ) value at pX, whether the percentile is of the form 'pX' or of the form 'pXpY'
longpop: The base unit is the individual (rather than the household) but resources are split equally within couples.
longage: The population is comprised of individuals over age 20.

shortname: Pre-tax labor income [total pre-tax income ranking]
simpledes: Pre-tax labor income  is the sum of all pre-tax personal income flows accruing to the individual owners of labor as a production factor, before taking into account the operation of the tax/transfer system, but after taking into account the operation of pension system. The central difference between personal factor income and pre-tax income is the treatment of pensions, which are counted on a contribution basis by factor income and on a distribution basis by pre-tax income.
technicaldes: Pre-tax labor income [total pre-tax income ranking]=Compensation of employees +Labor component of net mixed income +Pensions and social insurance income (labor share)
longtype: Percentile (i.e. threshold ) value at pX, whether the percentile is of the form 'pX' or of the form 'pXpY'
longpop: The base unit is the individual (rather than the household) but resources are split equally within couples.
longage: The population is comprised of individuals over age 20.

longtype: Ratio of net wealth (of a given sector) to net national income
longpop: The base unit is the individual (rather than the household). This is equivalent to assuming no sharing of resources within couples.
longage: The population is comprised of individuals of all ages.

shortname: Income reduction as a result of income tax
simpledes: Income reduction as a result of income tax is the total value of paid income taxes.
longtype: Ratio of net wealth (of a given sector) to net national income
longpop: The base unit is the individual (rather than the household). This is equivalent to assuming no sharing of resources within couples.
longage: The population is comprised of individuals over age 20.
source: Piketty T. and Zucman G. (2014), Capital is Back: Wealth-Income Ratios in Rich Countries 1700-2010, Quarterly Journal of Economics, 129(3): 1255-1310. Series updated by the same authors.;
method: Equal to 100*(1-Top 1% income share net of income tax/Top 1% income share).

shortname: Net Private Wealth to Net National Income Ratio
simpledes: Net Private Wealth to Net National Income Ratio is the division of net private wealth by net national income. Private wealth consists of net wealth of the personal sector (households) and the non-profit sector (philanthropy foundations, religious organizations, universities, etc.).
